articles.headline: For Obama, a Struggle to Win Over Key Blocs
articles.snippet: Democrats are wondering about what role race may be playing in Barack Obama’s difficulties in securing the nomination.
articles.abstract: Democrats are wondering about what role race may be playing in Barack Obama’s difficulties in securing the nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the question that has hung over Senator Barack Obama’s presidential campaign, and it loomed large on Tuesday night after his loss to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Pennsylvania: Why has he been unable to win over enough working-class and white voters to wrap up the Democratic nomination?

articles.headline: With First Car, a New Life in China
articles.snippet: As car sales soar in China, even first-time buyers are getting more sophisticated and want better cars.
articles.abstract: As car sales soar in China, even first-time buyers are getting more sophisticated and want better cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHUANG MIAO, China  Li Rifu packed a lot of emotional freight into his first car. Mr. Li, a 46-year-old farmer and watch repairman, and his wife secretly hoped a car would improve the odds of their sons, then 22 and 24, of finding girlfriends, marrying and producing grandchildren.

articles.headline: Apple Riding a 51% Jump in Mac Sales
articles.snippet: Buoyed by unusually strong Macintosh sales, the company grew notably faster than the rest of the computer market in the first three months of the year.
articles.abstract: Buoyed by unusually strong Macintosh sales, the company grew notably faster than the rest of the computer market in the first three months of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Signs of a consumer slowdown abound in the United States, but Apple customers appear not to have noticed.

articles.headline: Drug Executive Is Indicted on Secret Deal
articles.snippet: A former Bristol-Myers Squibb executive was charged with making false statements to the F.T.C. about a pact made with a Canadian maker of generic drugs.
articles.abstract: A former Bristol-Myers Squibb executive was charged with making false statements to the F.T.C. about a pact made with a Canadian maker of generic drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: A former senior vice president at Bristol-Myers Squibb has been indicted on federal charges of negotiating a secret pact between the company and a generic drug maker and then hiding the deal from federal regulators.

articles.headline: South Korea Faces Question of Corporate Control
articles.snippet: Following the resignation of the chairman of Samsung amid criminal indictments, South Korea seems uncertain about how much pressure to put on family-owned corporate groups.
articles.abstract: Following the resignation of the chairman of Samsung amid criminal indictments, South Korea seems uncertain about how much pressure to put on family-owned corporate groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea  It was a scene that stunned South Korea. Lee Kun-hee, the reclusive chairman of the Samsung Group, the conglomerate that dominates this country’s dynamic economy, abruptly resigned amid criminal indictments, apologizing in disgrace.

articles.headline: As Economy Slows, So Do Laser Eye Surgeries
articles.snippet: Call it the Lasik indicator. As consumers cut back on discretionary spending, the number of laser vision-correction surgeries has been falling.
articles.abstract: Call it the Lasik indicator. As consumers cut back on discretionary spending, the number of laser vision-correction surgeries has been falling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call it the Lasik indicator. With the weak economy forcing consumers to cut back on discretionary spending, the number of laser vision-correction surgeries has been falling  as it did during the last recession.

articles.headline: After the Smoke Cleared, Where Did All the Bingo Players Go?
articles.snippet: Banning smoking at charity bingo games may have health benefits, but it is proving harmful to earnings.
articles.abstract: Banning smoking at charity bingo games may have health benefits, but it is proving harmful to earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banning smoking at charity bingo games may have health benefits, but it is proving harmful to earnings.

articles.headline: At Expense of All Others, Putin Picks a Church
articles.snippet: The Kremlin has turned the Russian Orthodox Church into a de facto official religion, warding off other Christian denominations through a variety of harassing measures.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin has turned the Russian Orthodox Church into a de facto official religion, warding off other Christian denominations through a variety of harassing measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: STARY OSKOL, Russia  It was not long after a Methodist church put down roots here that the troubles began.

articles.headline: Democrats Assess Rivals’ Strength in Swing States
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton says she is best positioned to win in the fall, but exit polling shows that Barack Obama could do just as well.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton says she is best positioned to win in the fall, but exit polling shows that Barack Obama could do just as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reflecting on her victory in the Pennsylvania primary, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday neatly summed up the chief political rationale of her enduring candidacy.

articles.headline: Debt Collection Done From India Appeals to U.S. Agencies
articles.snippet: Debt collectors in India often cost about one-quarter the price of their American counterparts, and often do a better job, debt collection company executives say.
articles.abstract: Debt collectors in India often cost about one-quarter the price of their American counterparts, and often do a better job, debt collection company executives say.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India  In a glass tower on the outskirts of New Delhi, dozens of young Indians are on the telephone, calling America’s out of work, forgetful and debt-stricken and asking for cash.
